title: Agnes in the Game of Love
description: In Iduh's narrative, Okonkwo's character communicates in Nigerian Pidgin instead of Nigerian English, portraying his lower educational background and adding comedic value to the storyline. This linguistic choice enriches the plot by showcasing the diversity and social dynamics within the narrative.
source: "Agnes in the Game of Love" by Thomas Iduh
text: This thing don chop una head bad bad. Idon spoil una brain and na him make una papa dey talk to una, una go begin wordam like small boy.

title: Sap No Manna
description: The New Masquerade humorously portrays Chief Zebrudaya, who injects his speeches with bombastic English intertwined with ungrammatical Broken English. This blend serves as a comedic element in the sitcom, highlighting the playful interaction between formal and informal language in Nigerian settings.
source: The New Masquerade (sitcom) & "New Englishes: A West African Perspective"

title: Is English The Problem
description: In the Mark Angel Comedy series, Emmanuella relies on Nigerian Pidgin to communicate, while her uncle speaks a broken form of English. This linguistic contrast generates humor, often leading to misunderstandings, as seen when Mark Angel jokingly tries to sell the kids in a particular episode. These language choices contribute to the comedic essence of the series, creating entertaining scenarios based on language differences and playful misinterpretations.

title: NIGERIAN PIDGIN ENGLISH IN 6MINS | QUICK, EASY AND FUN (Ep1)
description: This video introduces various Nigerian Pidgin English terms and phrases, such as 'abeg' translating to 'please' and 'wetin' meaning 'what.' It serves as an informative guide, offering insights into the everyday usage and meanings behind these expressions within the Nigerian Pidgin lexicon.

description: This short humorously explores the way accents can adapt based on emotions and situations, showcasing how individuals might alter their speech when experiencing strong feelings such as anger or surprise.

title: Nairobi Law
description: The video features Richard Mwako whose direct way of speaking, mixing formal English with a few local sayings, reflects how Kenyan English is used in professional settings, showing how people balance formality with local expressions.

title: Nairobi Official Film
description: This short film showcases the everyday lives of young adults in Nairobi, reflecting the dynamics of relationships, trust, and complexities in romantic connections within the city. It offers insights into the use of Kenyan English within personal relationships, illustrating how characters balance colloquial expressions and local culture with their interactions in a modern urban setting.

title: BREAKING THE SPIRIT OF POVERTY
description: Rev Lucy Natasha's sermon, delivered in Kenyan English within the Nairobi City Center, demonstrates a unique linguistic blend. Her use of indigenous phrases interspersed with English not only resonates with her audience but also prompts reactions, emphasizing key points and fostering a connection. This strategic use of language underlines her message and fosters a strong rapport, inviting agreement and engagement from her listeners.

title: 5 Pronunciations That Are 100% Kenyan: Usha's 5 Things
description: This video glosses over some of the unique pronunciations that Kenyan English speakers use, including 'diagnosed', 'peugeot', and 'Maybelline.' It offers insights into the linguistic nuances of Kenyan English, showcasing how speakers adapt their pronunciation to reflect local culture and linguistic influences.

title: Food Billboards in Nairobi
description: In Nairobi, billboards predominantly showcase content in English, reflecting its status as a widely used language. However, the occasional billboard in another language (as seen on the right) underscores the city's rich cultural diversity and the inclusivity of local linguistic expressions amidst the prevalent use of English in public communication.

title: Understanding Cameroonian Pidgin English
description: In this video, Kenna goes over some of the basics of Cameroonian Pidgin English, including 'lie thing' for 'liar' and 'ndon' for 'not nice.'

title: RICHARD: EP 17- THE MESSENGER (BEST CAMEROON COMEDY)
description: In this comedy skit, Richard unwittingly gets entangled in a relationship predicament that is unrelated to him, where humor ensues, featuring slang and casual language elements reflective of local speech patterns.

title: Updated 2018 Summer Foundation Routine | OILY SKIN
description: In this makeup tutorial, the Cameroonian influencer uses a blend of Cameroonian Pidgin English and predominantly standard English to communicate with her audience.

title: Advertisement in Pidgin English, Buea
description: This advertisement in Buea, Cameroon, showcases the use of Cameroonian Pidgin English for a telephone company. In addition to the use of Pidgin English, the advertisement also features a line of Standard English.

title: Easter Sunday Reading in Pidgin English Published in 1984
description: This excerpt demonstrates the use of Pidgin English in the Sunday Lectionary, highlighting its linguistic capacity and effectiveness in religious education for Cameroonians over a century while showcasing the language's phonological and grammatical nuances.
